messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Motion Planning Diffusion: Learning and Planning of Robot Motions with Diffusion Models

Paper Abstract: Abstract Learning priors on trajectory distributions can help accelerate robot motion planning optimization. Given previously successful plans, learning trajectory generative models as priors for a new planning problem is highly desirable. Prior works propose several ways on utilizing this prior to bootstrapping the motion planning problem. Either sampling the prior for initializations or using the prior distribution in a maximum-a-posterior formulation for trajectory optimization. In this work, we propose learning diffusion models as priors. We then can sample directly from the posterior trajectory distribution conditioned on task goals, by leveraging the inverse denoising process of diffusion models. Furthermore, diffusion has been recently shown to effectively encode data multi-modality in high-dimensional settings, which is particularly well-suited for large trajectory dataset. To demonstrate our method efficacy, we compare our proposed method - Motion Planning Diffusion - against several baselines in simulated planar robot and 777-dof robot arm manipulator environments. To assess the generalization capabilities of our method, we test it in environments with previously unseen obstacles. Our experiments show that diffusion models are strong priors to encode high-dimensional trajectory distributions of robot motions. https://sites.google.com/view/mp-diffusion

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Planning Algorithms",
        "Chomp: Gradient optimization techniques for efficient motion planning",
        "Stomp: Stochastic trajectory optimization for motion planning",
        "Sampling-based robot motion planning: A review",
        "Modern Robotics: Mechanics, Planning, and Control",
        "Probabilistic roadmaps for path planning in high-dimensional configuration spaces",
        "Rapidly-exploring random trees: A new tool for path planning",
        "Rrt-connect: An efficient approach to single-query path planning",
        "Sampling-based algorithms for optimal motion planning",
        "Motion planning as probabilistic inference using Gaussian processes and factor graphs",
        "Continuous-time gaussian process motion planning via probabilistic inference",
        "Fast smoothing of manipulator trajectories using optimal bounded-acceleration shortcuts.",
        "Learning implicit priors for motion optimization",
        "A survey of learning-based robot motion planning",
        "Learning sampling distributions for robot motion planning",
        "Motion planning networks",
        "Demonstration based trajectory optimization for generalizable robot motions",
        "Towards robust skill generalization: Unifying learning from demonstration and motion planning",
        "Learning forceful manipulation skills from multi-modal human demonstrations",
        "Se(3)-diffusionfields: Learning smooth cost functions for joint grasp and motion optimization through diffusion",
        "Structured deep generative models for sampling on constraint manifolds in sequential manipulation",
        "An algorithmic perspective on imitation learning",
        "Deep unsupervised learning using nonequilibrium thermodynamics",
        "Denoising diffusion probabilistic models",
        "Generative modeling by estimating gradients of the data distribution",
        "High-resolution image synthesis with latent diffusion models",
        "Diffusionclip: Text-guided diffusion models for robust image manipulation",
        "Hierarchical text-conditional image generation with clip latents",
        "Diffusion models beat gans on image synthesis",
        "Motion planning transformers: A motion planning framework for mobile robots",
        "Deeply informed neural sampling for robot motion planning",
        "Neural rrt*: Learning-based optimal path planning",
        "No mcmc for me: Amortized sampling for fast and stable training of energy-based models",
        "Dall-e-bot: Introducing web-scale diffusion models to robotics",
        "Structdiffusion: Object-centric diffusion for semantic rearrangement of novel objects",
        "Denoising diffusion probabilistic models for styled walking synthesis",
        "Conditioned score-based models for learning collision-free trajectory generation",
        "Planning with diffusion for flexible behavior synthesis",
        "Is conditional generative modeling all you need for decision-making?",
        "Planning by probabilistic inference",
        "Robot trajectory optimization using approximate inference",
        "Reinforcement learning and control as probabilistic inference: Tutorial and review",
        "Relative entropy policy search",
        "Stochastic optimal control as approximate input inference",
        "Inferring smooth control: Monte carlo posterior policy iteration with gaussian processes",
        "Hierarchical policy blending as optimal transport",
        "Sparse Gaussian processes on matrix Lie groups: A unified framework for optimizing continuous-time trajectories",
        "Improved denoising diffusion probabilistic models",
        "Pytorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library",
        "A micro lie theory for state estimation in robotics",
        "Batch continuous-time trajectory estimation as exactly sparse gaussian process regression.",
        "Learning structured output representation using deep conditional generative models",
        "Differentiable gaussian process motion planning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Motion Planning Diffusion: Learning and Planning of Robot Motions with Diffusion Models, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
